content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Emma and Lily jog in the same direction along a straight track. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 15"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, Emma’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="E of t, equals, the fraction with numerator 7,510, and denominator t squared, minus 7 t, plus 80.22, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7510</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>80.22</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and Lily’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="L of t, equals, 12 times t cubed, times e raised to the negative 0.5 t power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="E of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 15"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and are measured in meters per minute, and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. Emma is <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> meters ahead of Lily at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and Emma remains ahead of Lily for <math alttext="0 less than t, less than or equal to 15"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the value of <math alttext="one sixth times, the integral from, 2 to 8, of, E of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="one sixth times, the integral from, 2 to 8, of, E of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Emma and Lily jog in the same direction along a straight track. For <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 15"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, Emma’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="E of t, equals, the fraction with numerator 7,510, and denominator t squared, minus 7 t, plus 80.22, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>7510</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>80.22</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and Lily’s velocity at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="L of t, equals, 12 times t cubed, times e raised to the negative 0.5 t power"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="E of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 15"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and are measured in meters per minute, and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. Emma is <math alttext="10"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> meters ahead of Lily at time <math alttext="t equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and Emma remains ahead of Lily for <math alttext="0 less than t, less than or equal to 15"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the value of <math alttext="one sixth times, the integral from, 2 to 8, of, E of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="one sixth times, the integral from, 2 to 8, of, E of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mfrac><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.
(b) At time <math alttext="t equals 5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is Emma speeding up or slowing down? Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Is the distance between Emma and Lily at time <math alttext="t equals 7"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing or decreasing? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) What is the maximum distance between Emma and Lily over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 15"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

topic.text: 4.2: Straight-Line Motion - Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
